pullRequest.body:
A Lean-linter implementation of the `#`-command linter introduced in #10809.

This linter produces a warning whenever a non-allowed `#`-command is used.  The allowed commands are
```lean
#align
#align_import
#noalign
#adaptation_note
```

[Zulip discussion](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/144837-PR-reviews/topic/.2311019.3A.20a.20syntax.20linter.20for.20.23-commands)

---

~~This PR is accompanied by #11028, which places the linter in `Tactic.Basic`, to make sure that (most of) `Mathlib` passes the `#`-command linter~~.

<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body: I like this much more than the sed version!
Thomas, thank you very much for your comments!  The new `withSetOptionIn'` command works great, thanks!  I added it and also put some tests in to ensure that it does what it should!

Hmm, I'm not *totally* sure about only linting the silent commands, because it's nice to have an error telling you explicitly what's wrong! But I do like having it show up outside of CI when there are no messages, and it definitely works. (The "noisy stdout" section of build tells you *where* the noise is happening, right?) I'd like someone else to sign off on that specific choice, since I'm not sure what the best option is there. Also see the comment on the earlier thread. (Sorry, maybe I should have just commented there!)

I [asked on Zulip](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/144837-PR-reviews/topic/.2311019.3A.20a.20syntax.20linter.20for.20.23-commands) about emitting an extra warning in CI, but I feel like I failed to communicate properly what the issue was.

I also accepted your suggestion of the extra warning when `warningAsError` is `true`.

@grunweg I should have fixed all the issues.  Since your review, the changes have been to
* allow `#adaptation_note` and
* fix a syntax bug with handling nested `set_option ... in` commands.

I also extended the list of tests and went ahead to lint most of mathlib!

Thanks for the quick response. I was wondering about #guard_msg; good catch!
Looking at the past logs, it seems #guard (in `test/vec_notation`) might also need to be allowed.

From my side, once CI passes, it's ready to be merged. (In particular, given the negligible performance effect.)

Michael, thank you for the reviews!

Re `#guard_msgs`: I simply silenced it, since it was quick and I do not expect lots of them to show up in `Mathlib`.  Probably a better solution would be to allow them only in `test` files, but I would leave this discussion for later.

Re `#guard`: I am happy not allowing it in `Mathlib`.  If I remember correctly, I actually removed some `#guard`s in `Mathlib` that were picked up by the linter and moved them to `test` files.
Ok, after yet another failed test, I decided to make the `#guard`s not allowed, except in `test` other than `test.HashCommandLinter`.  I hope that this time the tests pass!

Tests pass; I took one last look and pushed a few tiny tweaks. (@adomani Feel free to revert those if you prefer!)
I think this lint is ready to go: performance is good, mathlib passes, no bad test changes or anything that looks questionable. Thank you for your work on this, this one took a while - but I'm glad it lands!
maintainer merge

(A follow-up PR could remove the sed-based linter this replaces. Imho, this doesn't have to happen in this PR.)
🚀 Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by grunweg.
Filed #13142 for the follow-up.

Thanks :tada:

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9218346948/job/25361730857)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9218346948/job/25361730644)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9218346948/job/25361730792)
Thank you for doing this. I only have minor comments.

This review seems bigger than it is. It's basically:
* style/documentation
* code tweaking/taking care of edge cases
* questions about a couple of details

This PR looks very nice! :)

Thomas, as usual, thank you very much for your thorough review!  I accepted/adapted your suggestions!

I am still digesting the `withSetOptionIn'` suggestion and will report back on that!

Apologies for the delay—very close to looking good to me! :) (Also see comment about `withSetOptionIn'` which is not organized as part of this review.)

I would like to see if we can run this during CI if possible by hijacking the `warningAsError` option (only until the underlying issue is fixed, of course)—see comment.
Thank you for doing this. I only have minor comments.

Oh, I thought that I had replied to those previous messages, but they got lost in review!

Anyway, I ended up allowing more `#guards`!
I don't think this should be enabled by default, but it should be enabled in CI (can do so in this PR). What do you think?

I actually think that I prefer it to be disabled by default outside of CI: if I am using `#eval` in a file, I expect to want to see the output and not be bugged by the linter!  I'll look up how to make sure that CI uses a different default.
Yeah I agree exactly, I think its enoguh to call lean in CI with `-Dlinter.hashCommand=true`

I am failing to make this work locally:
```
$ lake build Mathlib.mwe
[303/304] Building Mathlib.mwe
error: > LEAN_PATH=./.lake/packages/std/.lake/build/lib:./.lake/packages/Qq/.lake/build/lib:./.lake/packages/aesop/.lake/build/lib:./.lake/packages/proofwidgets/.lake/build/lib:./.lake/packages/Cli/.lake/build/lib:./.lake/packages/importGraph/.lake/build/lib:./.lake/build/lib LD_LIBRARY_PATH=./.lake/build/lib /home/damiano/.elan/toolchains/leanprover--lean4---v4.6.0-rc1/bin/lean -Dlinter.hashCommand=true -Dpp.unicode.fun=true -Dpp.proofs.withType=false -DautoImplicit=false -DrelaxedAutoImplicit=false ./././Mathlib/mwe.lean -R ././. -o ./.lake/build/lib/Mathlib/mwe.olean -i ./.lake/build/lib/Mathlib/mwe.ilean -c ./.lake/build/ir/Mathlib/mwe.c
error: stderr:
invalid -D parameter, unknown configuration option 'linter.hashCommand'
error: external command `/home/damiano/.elan/toolchains/leanprover--lean4---v4.6.0-rc1/bin/lean` exited with code 1
```

I modified this
```lean
  weakLeanArgs :=
    if get_config? CI |>.isSome then
      #["-DwarningAsError=true", "-Dlinter.hashCommand=true"]
    else
      #["-Dlinter.hashCommand=true"]
```

Alex, it seems that it is not an option to make this linter quiet locally, but chatty on CI.  I propose to make the linter available with quiet default: hopefully in the future it will be possible to set different defaults globally and then the linter would reach its full potential!

Hmm, it's a hack to work around it now, but: what if we made the `defValue := true`, yet *also* checked `warningAsError` in the linter (and left a very visible note, and even made the description ``"enables the `#`-command linter as long as `warningAsError` is `true`"``)? I.e.
```lean
def getLinterHash (o : Options) : Bool :=
  Linter.getLinterValue linter.hashCommand o && warningAsError.get o
```
Then it would run in CI (since that uses `warningAsError := true`) but not locally under normal circumstances.

I guess the question is: in practice, would someone want to turn on this linter locally? Or is it ok if it's only ever run in CI?

(Another option is to keep `defValue := false` but turn it on whenever `warningAsError := true`, i.e. using `||` instead of `&&` above.)

For me, the main use of this linter while working on a PR, would be when a `#`-command is silent.  If I am using a "noisy" `#`-command, I am probably curious about its output and adding the linter warning would be annoying.

If there were a way of making the linter noisy exactly when the `#`-command is not, then I would like it always on, I think.

Having it on while editing when there are no messages is a good idea! I do wonder whether it should *also* be on everywhere during CI for good error messages (as mentioned elsewhere). I guess the logic would be `getLinterHash (<- getOptions) && ((<- get).messages.msgs.size == 0 || warningAsError.get (<- getOptions))` in that case. I won't insist on this, though! :)

```suggestion
beginning with `#`.  For example, `#eval`, `#guard`, `#guard_msgs` all trigger a message.
```
Why do we demand that `a` contains no spaces?
Removed, see above for an explanation.

Whitelist is a single word! :)
```suggestion
/-- `whitelist` is the array of `#`-commands that are allowed in 'Mathlib'. -/
private abbrev whitelist : Array String := #["#align", "#align_import", "#noalign"]
```

```suggestion
`whitelist`. -/
```

```suggestion
    if ("#".isPrefixOf a && (!' ' ∈ a.toList) && whitelist.all (· != a)) then
```

In a circumstance like this we should be `push`ing instead of `++`ing, I think—the latter creates a new array each time we use it, I believe.

Though, since we only ever use the *first* atom down below, why not simply get the first atom (and fail if there isn't one)?
```suggestion
def getInitialAtomStx? : Syntax → Option Syntax
  | .node _ _ args => match args[0]? with | s@(some (Syntax.atom ..)) => s | _ => none
  | _ => none
```
Then later, we'd want `if let some sa := getInitialAtomStx? stx then` (with no `else`).

(We could also extend the match with `| some s@(Syntax.node ..) => getInitialAtomStx? s` to be safer, but this is annoyingly not obviously terminating to Lean, and would need a `termination_by` or `partial`.)

(Caveat emptor: I haven't tested that this works! :) )

This is a remnant of an earlier version of the linter, where I would list all atoms and scan for the ones beginning with `#` to try and do the "burrowing" that you mention above.  This is also why I later excluded spaces, since I wanted to discard matching on `# Section` in doc-modules.  I also removed the check for spaces below.
Do we need `(← getInfoState).enabled`? I don't think we're touching infotrees here, right?
Removed!

```suggestion
        [linter.hashCommand]"
```

Note that this linter currently only fires on `#`-commands which are themselves initial at the top level or follow a `set_option`. (However, we should also burrow to the syntax following `in` in general. See the `withSetOption` line below.) That's the case for most of the ones we want to keep out, so I think this is fine, but excludes commands like `#guard_msgs` which occur after the first atom (as the parser uses `docComment` first). This should be documented or changed—I think it's ok to document, though.

In doing so this should also communicate that use of the commands deeper in syntax is not linted against. Maybe it would be good to have a test showing this, e.g.
```
macro "run " c:command : command => pure c

run #eval 0
```

We should also discard syntax like `variable ... in` and `open ... in` before linting. We can do that with something like the following, which is mostly cargo-culted from `withSetOptionIn`, but splits on the nodekind of the thing before `in`. (Not tested in this file, since my computer is slow and switching branches in VS code right now is a hassle! :P Definitely deserves tests.)

```suggestion

open Command in
/-- Exactly like `withSetOptionIn`, but recursively discards any other use of `in`. -/
private partial def withSetOptionIn' (cmd : CommandElab) : CommandElab := fun stx => do
  if stx.getKind == ``Lean.Parser.Command.in then
    if stx[0].getKind == ``Lean.Parser.Command.set_option then
      let opts ← Elab.elabSetOption stx[0][1] stx[0][2]
      Command.withScope (fun scope => { scope with opts }) do
        withSetOptionIn' cmd stx[1]
    else
      withSetOptionIn' cmd stx[1]
  else
    cmd stx

/-- Checks that no command beginning with `#` is present in 'Mathlib', except for the ones in
`whiteList`. -/
def hashCommandLinter : Linter where run := withSetOptionIn' fun stx => do
```

Many apologies for the delay here—I didn't see this comment and thought you were still digesting it! 😅 (And for the past few days I've been a bit busy.)

There's a good reason my suggestion didn't work: it's wrong! :) I cargo-culted from `withSetOptionIn`, and there's a bug in `withSetOptionIn`. (leanprover/lean4#3806) Namely, it should recurse into `stx[2]` (the command syntax), not `stx[1]` (which is the token `"in"`). You'll notice that currently,
```lean
set_option lean.hashCommand true in
#print 0
```
doesn't work as expected.

So it should actually be 
```lean
open Command in
/-- Exactly like `withSetOptionIn`, but recursively discards any other use of `in`. Intended to be 
used in the hashcommand linter, where we don't need to handle non-`set_option` `in` commands. -/
private partial def withSetOptionIn' (cmd : CommandElab) : CommandElab := fun stx => do
  if stx.getKind == ``Lean.Parser.Command.in then
    if stx[0].getKind == ``Lean.Parser.Command.set_option then
      let opts ← Elab.elabSetOption stx[0][1] stx[0][2]
      Command.withScope (fun scope => { scope with opts }) do
        withSetOptionIn' cmd stx[2]
    else
      withSetOptionIn' cmd stx[2]
  else
    cmd stx
```
Note also that since `#guard_msgs in` doesn't actually use the `Lean.Parser.Command.in` parser for `in` (its `" in"` is defined in its own syntax, unlike e.g. `set_option ... in`), it's exempt from `withSetOptionIn'`. (This is also why the linter doesn't fire twice in each `#guard_msgs` test: at the top level, it hits the docstring on `#guard_msgs` and stops, which is actually quite useful.)

A good test for `withSetOptionIn'` would of course be something like
```lean
variable [Nonempty x] in
#synth Nonempty x
```

Since the only reason this linter doesn't catch `#guard_msgs` is the presence of a preceding docstring, and since I'm pretty sure that's unique to `#guard_msgs`, I'm okay with `#guard_msgs` not being linted against! Linting against `#guard_msgs` would also make testing the linter itself difficult. Especially since an accidental `#guard_msgs` would be (I think!) very rare.

I'm happy to push these changes if it would be convenient for you (I've now tested them locally), but if you'd like to make them yourself that's fine too! :)

```suggestion
    | some sa =>
      let a := sa.getAtomVal
      if ("#".isPrefixOf a && whitelist.all (· != a)) then
        logWarningAt sa f!"`#`-commands, such as '{a}', are not allowed in 'Mathlib'\n\
          [linter.hashCommand]"
    | none => return
```
I removed the indent, eventually!

I wonder if we should import this in `Mathlib.Tactic.Common`, since it uses no theory files, to get it earlier in the hierarchy? What's the reasoning behind importing it here, and/or do you know if this has been discussed anywhere?

I'm also wondering if the file itself should be in new folders: Mathlib > Command > Linter > HashCommand.lean. It's a bit odd for me to see a linter in `Tactic`, but `GuardMsgs` was in `Std.Tactic`, so there is precedent for command-related things being in `Tactic`...though I think it might be nice to start having linters in their own folder one way or another! I'd like to start the discussion on zulip unless it's been discussed already.

But! I won't hold up this PR on this basis. We can always move things around later. :)

I already have an accompanying PR where I import the linter in `Mathlib.Tactic.Basic`, since I wanted to test the linter on (most of) Mathlib.

As for moving linters to a separate folder, I think that this is a good idea, but maybe I would leave that for a second PR: there is also a `Tactic.Lint` file that should probably move there as well.
The PR with this linter imported early should be #11028.
Sounds good! :)

I hope `Std.Lean.HashSet` gets upstreamed, because then you could write `{ "#align", "#align_import", "#noalign" }` without adding an import! :) Up to you if you want to prioritize fewer imports or shorter syntax, just wanted to mention it.
I like the notation and was not aware of it!  I added the import, since this linter is going into Mathlib, I take a nonchalant stance to "assuming" `Core` and `Std` files.

Did the module check get lost in the mix here, or is this intentional?
```suggestion
  if getLinterHash (← getOptions) && (← get).messages.msgs.size == 0 &&
     (currentModule.getRoot == `Mathlib || currentModule == `test.HashCommandLinter) then
```

I intentionally made the linter check everything, including *all* `test` files.  I am not completely convinced by the change, but now you *can* unlint test files, whereas before you did not have the option to lint them, no matter what.

The PR which really makes the linter active (#11028) needed some relatively minor adjustment, but maybe I would leave the discussion of whether `test`s are in scope for the linter to that PR?
Nit: this is a double space, right?
Removed.

How about simply
```suggestion
There is a list of silent `#`-command that are allowed.
```
In this case, there is no local variable `whitelist` (and this doubles the remaining doc-string anyway). In addition, in my experience "blacklist" and "whitelist" (while having possible ungood underpinnings related to race) can often be rephrased in a clearer way by avoiding them. This feels like such an instance.

This might be clearer as `allowed_commands`, like
```lean
/-- Array of `#`-commands which are allowed in `Mathlib`. -/
private abbrev allowed_commands : HashSet String :=
```
... then this could be "for the explicitly allowed ones".
Renamed!

Long-term, I'd really appreciate if all Lean and mathlib linters had an explanation "why is this [code pattern what we're linting] bad". For instance, in Rust, the clippy linter has these ([example](https://rust-lang.github.io/rust-clippy/master/index.html#/absolute_paths), and I found them *really* helpful.

Not strictly required, but: do you mind adding one or two sentences on why we want this?
Comment added.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: syntax linter for `#`-commands

source.title: [Merged by Bors] - chore: a non-lean linter for #-commands
